questions.text: Where does the limbal part of conjunctiva derive its blood supply from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Limbal Conjunctiva Supplied by both the posterior conjunctival artery (a branch of the peripheral arcade) and the anterior conjunctival artery (a branch of the anterior ciliary).
  • Marginal Conjunctiva:Supplied by the marginal arcade of the eyelid.
  • Forniceal Conjunctiva:Supplied by the peripheral arcade of the eyelid.

questions.text: Sub-mandibular nodes receive lymphatics from which part of conjunctiva?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lymphatic drainage is to the submandibular nodes, which drain the medial one-third of the superior conjunctiva and the medial two-thirds of the inferior conjunctiva.
  • The preauricular nodes, which drain the lateral two-thirds of the superior conjunctiva and the lateral one-third of the inferior conjunctiva. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: The Aqueous layer is secreted by goblet cells.
The Aqueous layer is secreted by the glands of Manz.
The Aqueous layer is secreted by lacrimal glands and glands of Krause and Wolfring.
The Aqueous layer is secreted by the meibomian glands.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tear film secretion is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The conjunctival surface is lubricated by the tear film, which is a triple-layered sandwich consisting of the following:

Middle aqueous layer :

  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory conjunctival glands of Krause, found along the inferior and superior fornices of the conjunctival sac and Wolfring or Ciaccio, which are small tubular glands located near the upper tarsal border in the upper eyelid.

Innermost mucinous layer :

  • Lining the conjunctival cells and corneal epithelium are secreted by the goblet cells, crypts of Henle, which are infoldings of the conjunctiva, and glands of Manz, which are located in a ring around the margin of the cornea. (Options A and B ruled out)

Outermost superficial lipid layer:

  • Secreted by the meibomian glands, which are vertically oriented sebaceous glands found within the tarsal plate and open along the eyelid margins, and limit the evaporation of tears. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is not a commensal in the normal conjunctival sac?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoea is not a commensal and is a pathogenic organism.
  • Most of the organisms normally present, such as Staphylococcus albus or S. epidermidis, diphtheroids, Propionibacterium acnes, Neisseria catarrhalis, Corynebacterium xerosis, etc, are nonpathogenic commensals, but some of them are morphologically identical with pathogenic types. (Options A, B and C ruled out)
  • Staphylococci are often found and are relatively innocuous in the absence of other organisms, but play an important part in mixed infections.
  • Streptococcus, Escherichia coli, Bacillus Proteus, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Haemophilus aegyptius and Moraxella are pathogenic and rarely found in normal eyes.

choices.text: Histopathology reveals aggregation of lymphocytes in sub-epithelial adenoid layer
Overlying conjunctiva usually remains normal
Reaction can be identified in new-born children suffering from conjunctivits
Upper palpebral conjunctiva is more frequently involved than lower in trachoma

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the pathology depicted in the picture are correct excep?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Follicles are not seen in newborns, as the conjunctiva at birth lacks lymphoid tissue.
  • Follicular conjunctivitis is characterized by follicles, which are yellowish-white, round elevations (1-2 mm in diameter) formed by localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the subepithelial adenoid layer. (Option A)
  • The overlying conjunctival epithelium remains normal, unless acute inflammation is present. (Option B)
  • In trachoma, the upper palpebral conjunctiva is more frequently affected than the lower, with typical follicle formation and scarring. (Option D)

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for the development of the pathology depicted in the picture below, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above image is of Subconjunctival haemorrhage, also called subconjunctival ecchymosis, which is due to the rupture of small vessels.
  • Rickets affects bone mineralisation due to vitamin D deficiency.
  • It does not cause capillary fragility or spontaneous haemorrhage like scurvy.
  • The condition, though unsightly, is trivial.

Treatment:

  • It is self-resolving in two to three weeks' time.
  • No treatment is required.

Other causes include:

  • Bleeding disorders (e.g., haemophilia, thrombocytopenia)
  • Anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy (e.g., warfarin, aspirin, clopidogrel)
  • Diabetes mellitus (due to microvascular fragility)
  • Liver disease (affects coagulation)
  • Severe infections (e.g., dengue fever)

Explanation of other options:

Systolic hypertension(Option A): This can occur spontaneously in elderly people with fragile vessels or those with systolic hypertension, or after local ocular trauma or eye surgery.

Heavy weight lifting(Option B): Very minute ecchymoses, or possibly thromboses, are seen in severe conjunctivitis; large extravasations accompany severe straining, especially in old people, such as on lifting heavy weights or vomiting.

Scurvy(Option C): They are not infrequently seen in children with whooping cough and may occur in scurvy, in blood diseases such as purpura or in malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with the pathology depicted in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image given depicts a case of Chemosis of the conjunctiva. Retinal vein occlusion is least likely to cause chemosis.
  • Chemosis, otherwise known as oedema of the conjunctiva, is due to exudation from the abnormally permeable capillaries. The exudate is retained within the mucous membrane, which becomes swollen and gelatinous in appearance, particularly in the loosely attached areas of the bulbar conjunctiva and fornices. It may occur in the following:
  • Acute inflammations: The inflammation may be in the conjunctiva, as in gonorrhoeal conjunctivitis, or within the eyeball, as in panophthalmitis or hypopyon ulcer; it is also occasionally found in acute glaucoma. The inflammation may be in the accessory structures of the eye, such as a stye or an insect bite on the lid, dacryocystitis, periostitis, orbital cellulitis or meningitis.
  • Obstruction to the circulation: The pressure of an orbital tumour may interfere with the lymph and blood drainage so as to produce chemosis; it is also found in pulsating exophthalmos or dysthyroid eye disease.
  • Systemic conditions: This group includes nephritis, severe anaemia, urticaria, angioneurotic oedema and occasionally lymphomatous infiltration.

Explanation of other options:

Dacryocystitis(Option A): The explanation mentions that chemosis may occur in acute inflammations, including conditions like dacryocystitis, where there is an inflammation of the lacrimal sac. This justifies why option A is correct.

Urticaria(Option B): The explanation includes urticaria in the list of systemic conditions that may lead to chemosis. This justifies why option B is correct.

Dysthyroidism(Option C): The explanation mentions that chemosis may occur due to obstruction to circulation, such as in dysthyroidism or dysthyroid eye disease. This justifies why option C is correct.vvvvv

questions.text: Which type of conjunctival secretions are most likely seen in Vernal Kerato-Conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vernal Kerato-Conjunctivitis (VKC) is a chronic, allergic eye condition that typically affects young males, especially in warm climates.
  • It is characterised by:
    • Intense itching
    • Photophobia
    • Giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctivae
    • Limbal hypertrophy
    • Shield ulcers in some cases
  • A hallmark feature of VKC is thick, ropy or stringy mucous discharge due to the excessive production of mucus from conjunctival goblet cells.
  • The stringy discharge differentiates VKC from infective conjunctivitis, where secretions are typically mucoid (Option A), mucopurulent, or purulent.

The nature of the secretion is of diagnostic importance:

  • Bacterial: Muco-purulent/ purulent(Option B)
  • Viral: Serous(Option C)
  • Allergic (VKC): White stringy/ ropy
  • Acute allergic ( Bee sting): Chemosis+lidoedemaa

questions.text: Which of the following microbial organisms is not likely associated with acute blennorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Moraxella is associated with angular conjunctivitis and is least likely to cause acute blepharitis.
  • A particularly severe form of acute purulent conjunctivitis is that due to gonorrhoeae. (Option A)
  • It is associated with moderate to severe pain and lid swelling with copious purulent discharge and tender, sometimes suppurative, preauricular lymphadenopathy.
  • In typical cases, the discharge reaccumulates within seconds of cleaning. This form of conjunctivitis is also termed 'hyperacute' conjunctivitis or acute blepharoconjunctivitis by
  • Gonococcal conjunctivitis occurs in two forms: as ophthalmia neonatorum in newborn babies and as severe purulent conjunctivitis in adults.
  • Apart from N. gonorrhoeae, infection with Neisseria meningitides, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species, especially beta-haemolytic streptococci, Aegyptus and enteric Gram-negative bacilli can also present in this manner. (Options B and C ruled out)

choices.text: Topical antibiotics are mainstay in treatment.
Topical steroid use is not indicated.
Systemic antibiotics will be required in pre-septal cellulitis.
Use of bandage is recommended for associated photophobia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding management of bacterial conjunctivitis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Use of bandage is contraindicated as it prevents drainage of secretions and increases local temperature, and promotes bacterial growth.

Management of Bacterial Conjunctivitis:

  • Topical antibiotics: Broad-spectrum drugs (Ofloxacin/ chloramphenicol) 4-6 times a day (Option A)
  • Topical steroids: Not indicated (Option B)
  • Systemic antibiotics: in case of pyrexia/ pre-septal cellulitis (Option C)
  • For photophobia, sunglasses can be used.
  • A pad and bandage can promote the growth of more bacteria

questions.text: Which microbial organism is associated with Swimming pool conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chlamydial inclusion conjunctivitis is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D-K.
  • In adults, the infection is most commonly transmitted via sexual contact from a genital source, but it can also spread through contaminated water in swimming pools, hence the term 'swimming pool conjunctivitis.'
  • The disease often presents as a chronic follicular conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge, mild keratitis, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.
  • Neonates can acquire the infection during birth (ophthalmia neonatorum).
  • Serotypes A, B, and C instead cause trachoma, which is unrelated to swimming pool outbreaks. (Option C ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): S. aureus is a common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis, presenting with acute purulent discharge, lid swelling, and conjunctival congestion. However, it is not linked to swimming pool conjunctivitis, which is specifically caused by Chlamydia trachomatis D-K.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option B): Part of the normal conjunctival flora and generally non-pathogenic. It may rarely cause opportunistic infections in compromised individuals, but it does not cause epidemic or swimming pool-related conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following infections are least likely to be associated with C.trachomatis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mastoiditis is not typically associated with Chlamydia trachomatis. Instead, it is caused by bacteria from the Streptococcus and Staphylococcus families of cocci.

Chlamydia trachomatis:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is a bacterium that can cause various infections.
  • It is associated with both genital and oculogenital infections.

Associations with Chlamydia trachomatis include:

  • Non-gonococcal and post-gonococcal urethritis (Option B).
  • Cervicitis (Option C).
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis (Option A)
  • Salpingitis
  • Epididymitis
  • Bartholinitis
  • Reiter disease.
  • About half of the cases of reactive inflammatory arthritis occurring as a sequel to sexually acquired non-gonococcal genital tract infections are associated with C. trachomatis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with chronic follicular conjunctival reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Adenoviral infection is not associated with chronic follicular conjunctival reaction.
  • Adenoviral infections typically present as acute follicular conjunctivitis, which is characterised by the sudden onset of redness, discharge, and the formation of follicles on the conjunctiva.

Explanation of other options:

Pediculosis (Option A): It is an infestation of lice, can lead to chronic follicular conjunctival reaction. Lice infestation in the eyelashes can cause irritation and inflammation of the

conjunctiva, leading to the formation of follicles.

Pilocarpine use (Option B): Pilocarpine is a medication used to treat conditions like glaucoma and dry mouth. Pilocarpine eye drops can cause chronic follicular conjunctival reaction as a side effect. This is a well-documented adverse reaction associated with the use of pilocarpine eye drops.

Trachoma (Option C): Trachoma is an eye infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is known to cause chronic follicular conjunctival reaction. It is one of the common causes of this condition, characterised by the presence of follicles on the conjunctiva.

choices.text: Treatment is non-specific: Lubricants plus anti-microbials to prevent secondary infection
Topical anti-viral Acyclovir is drug of choice

questions.text:
A 24-year-old student presents to OPD with watering, redness, pain, and photophobia in both eyes for the last 2/3 days. Multiple family members are having similar complaints. On examination, follicular conjunctival reaction and corneal sub-epithelial opacities are noted. Clinical imaging is as depicted below.

Which of the following statements regarding this case is/ are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above picture is of Epidemic Kerato-conjunctivitis:

  • Causative organism: This disease is usually caused by adenovirus of serotypes 8 and 19, but also of serotypes 3 and 7. (Option A)

Clinical features:

  • Characterised by a rapidly developing follicular conjunctivitis with marked inflammatory symptoms and scant exudate, associated with a preauricular lymphadenopathy.
  • The infection is highly contagious, spreading rapidly through direct contact, fomites, or respiratory droplets. (Option B)
  • Occasionally, it takes on a membranous form 7-10 days after the infection.
  • Corneal complications appear initially as punctate epithelial infiltrates, followed by the development of discrete subepithelial opacities associated with photophobia.

Management:

  • Treatment is nonspecific, with mild decongestive and lubricant drops to relieve discomfort and antibiotic drops to prevent secondary bacterial infection. (Option C)
  • Specific antiviral therapy is not necessary.
  • Acyclovir is not effective against adenovirus infection

questions.text: Which viral infections present as haemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Haemorrhagic conjunctivitis:

  • Haemorrhagic conjunctivitis is due to picornaviruses, namely coxsackievirus and enterovirus 70.
  • Enterovirus 70 is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis and occurs in a pandemic form, producing a violent inflammatory conjunctivitis with lacrimation and photophobia.
  • Subconjunctival haemorrhages and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes are common. The cornea is usually affected.

Explanation of other options:

Orthopox virus(Option A): Causes diseases like smallpox and monkeypox, not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

Herpes virus(Option C): Causes Dendritic kerato-conjunctivitis + vesicular blepharitis skin lesions.

Newcastle virus(Option D): A paramyxovirus affecting birds, rarely causes conjunctivitis in humans, and it usually causes Pharyngo-conjunctivitis.

choices.text: Trachoma is caused by C.Trachomatis sero-types A/B/C
C.trachomatis is an obligate intra-cellular parasite
Trachoma is endemic in developing countries like India and Pakistan
Trachoma has racial predilection for black race

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Chlamydia trachomatis is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trachoma is linked to poverty and hygiene, not race.
  • Trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A, B and C, so called because it seemed to have a cloak (chlamydos) to the original observers, Ludwig Halberstaedter and Stanislaus von Prowazek. (Option A)
  • The organism is classified as a special type of bacterium, which is a prokaryotic, obligatory intracellular parasite, and the two species of the genus are C. trachomatis and C. psittaci. (Option B)
  • It is now endemic in many parts of the world, particularly parts of the Eastern Mediterranean region, the Middle East, South West (Iraq and Iran) and Central Asia, drier regions of the Indian subcontinent (India, Pakistan and Bangladesh), Eastern Asia (China and Japan), Indonesia, the Pacific Islands, North and Central Africa, and Central and large areas of South America. No race is exempt. (Option C)

choices.text: papillae gives velvety appearance on conjunctiva
Initial symptoms are non specific- foreign body sensation/ irritation/ discharge
Characterisitic follicles are mainly seen in lower fornix

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Trachoma infection is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Characteristic follicles in trachoma are primarily found in the upper tarsal conjunctiva, not the lower fornix.

Trachoma:

  • Trachoma is the world's leading cause of preventable, irreversible blindness. It is related to poverty, overcrowding and poor hygiene, the morbidity being a consequence of the establishment of re-infection cycles within communities.
  • Whereas an isolated episode of trachomatous conjunctivitis may be relatively innocuous, recurrent infection elicits a chronic immune response consisting of a cell-mediated delayed hypersensitivity (Type IV).

Source of infection:

  • It spreads by the transfer of conjunctival secretions through fingers or towels and, above all, by flies, which are attracted by the presence of profuse ocular discharge. (Option A)
  • On the other hand, scrupulous cleanliness prevents the extension of the disease to healthy subjects.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • It is mainly associated with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation and discharge. (Option C)
  • When chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation and photophobia and later blurring and finally severe loss of vision.

Signs:

  • These include conjunctival congestion, papillary enlargement and the development of follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Papillary hypertrophy of the tarsal conjunctiva gives a typical velvety appearance, an important clinical sign in active trachoma. (Option B)
  • The essential lesion is the trachomatous follicle. Their distribution is characteristic.
  • They may commence in the lower fornix, but in most cases, they quickly appear in the upper fornix as well, where they are usually most accentuated, often forming a row along the upper margin of the tarsus as well as generally over the palpebral conjunctiva. They are rare on the bulbar conjunctiva.

Diagnosis:

  • A simplified micro-immunofluorescence (micro-IF) test using pooled antigens rather than individual trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC) serotypes has been developed, which is recommended for routine diagnostic use.
  • Culture of C. trachomatis in irradiated McCoy cells is an expensive test.
  • Monoclonal antibody direct tests. IgA-IPA light microscopy tests form the best combination of diagnostic tools for chlamydial ocular disease.

questions.text: Identify the lesion depicted in the picture below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesion shown in the figure is Trachomatous Pannus.

Trachomatous pannus:

  • Lymphoid infiltration with vascularisation of the margin of the cornea, usually limited to the upper half but tending to spread towards the centre and to involve the whole cornea.
  • The upper part of the margin of the cornea becomes cloudy, and minute superficial vessels, springing from the corneal loops, grow inwards towards the centre.
  • The haziness and vascularisation increase until the upper half of the cornea is affected.

Explanation of other options:

Follicular reaction(Option A): aggregation of lymphocytes in the adenoid layer of the conjunctiva

Papillary reaction(Option B): vascular hyperplasia within the conjunctiva

Herbert pits(Option C): These are the follicular reaction specific to Trachoma, occurring at the limbus and are the pathognomic feature of trachoma.

questions.text: All of the following are known complications of Trachoma infection except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ankyloblepharon refers to the adhesion of the upper and lower eyelids to each other and is not a known complication of Trachoma infection.
  • It is usually congenital or results from trauma, burns, or other specific conditions.

Sequelae of Trachoma infection:

  • Apart from the results of pannus and corneal ulceration, the most disabling effects of trachoma are caused by distortion of the lids.
  • A peculiar drooping of the upper lids owing to dense infiltration is very characteristic, giving a sleepy appearance to the patient (trachomatous ptosis). (Option B)
  • There is always some scarring and, when extensive, it alters the shape of the lids, especially the upper lid, a change aided by the infiltration of the tarsus, causing softening and later alteration of its fibrous tissue.
  • By the later contraction of the newly formed scar tissue, the lid margins may be turned inwards (entropion), causing the lashes to rub against the cornea, often with disastrous effects (trichiasis). (Option B and D)
  • In late stages, the tarsal plate may also become thickened (tylosis). Ankyloblepharon is the adhesion of the upper and lower eyelids. which is congenital, usually

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical stage of Trachoma that can be observed according to the WHO classification?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Papillae are seen in trachoma but are not included in the WHO staging.

(Options A, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following are treatment options for Trachoma as per WHO, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • While fluoroquinolones can be effective, they are not the primary antibiotics recommended by the WHO for trachoma treatment.
  • Azithromycin and tetracycline are the preferred choices.
  • The WHO has recommended a combination of interventions to treat trachoma and limit its blinding consequences.

Treatment known by the acronym SAFE:

  • Surgery for cicatricial entropion and trichiasis(Option A)
  • Antibiotics are used to eliminate the organism.
  • Facial cleanliness to avoid infection (Option C)
  • Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation. (Option D)

Antibiotics:

  • Antibiotics used to eradicate the organism are administered as topical medication, tetracycline 1% eye ointment three times a day for a month OR azithromycin 1% eyedrops four times a day for 2 weeks.
  • Mass chemo prophylaxis in trachoma is indicated when in children between 1-9 has prevalence in > 10 %.
  • Systemic medication: a single oral dose of azithromycin 1 g is effective.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Perinaud's oculoglandular syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Perinaud's Oculo-Glandular Syndrome is characterised by:

  • Unilateral Follicular Conjunctivitis(Option A)
  • Ipsilateral submandibular or pre-auricular lymphadenopathy(Option C)
  • Fever, malaise and skin rash(Option D)

Causes:

  • Infectious: Rochalimaea henselae (cat-scratch disease), tularaemia, tuberculosis, other mycobacterial infections, mumps, infectious mononucleosis, fungal infections, lymphogranuloma venereum and syphilis.
  • Noninfectious: sarcoidosis, lymphoma and leukaemia.

choices.text: It presents within 48 hours of birth
It presents as purulent bilateral conjunctivitis
Infection remains confined to the conjunctiva

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding newborn infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ophthalmia Neonatorum:

  • It is a preventable disease occurring in a newborn child due to maternal infection acquired at the time of birth by contamination in the birth passage.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae conjunctivitis manifests the earliest, typically within the first 48 hours of birth. In cases of virulent gonococcal infection, the discharge rapidly becomes mucopurulent and then purulent. (Option A and B)
  • Both eyes are nearly always affected, with one usually worse than the other. The conjunctiva becomes intensely inflamed, bright red and swollen, with a thick yellow pus discharge.
  • Marked chemosis is a distinguishing feature from severe mucopurulent conjunctivitis. May present as membranous conjunctivitis.
  • As gonococci have the power of invading intact epithelium, there is a risk of corneal ulceration and perforation in untreated gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum.
  • trachomatis is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum. It presents classically after 1 week of birth. BL crepts can also be seen in these children.

Management:

  • Ceftriaxone injection i.m. (Option D).
  • Gentamicin drops
  • BacitracinEyee Ointment.
  • Mass chemo prophylaxis in trachoma is indicated when in children between 1-9 has a prevalence of> 10 % and is done with Azithromycin.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is implicated in chemical conjunctivitis in newborns?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chemical toxicity used to be seen within a few hours of prophylactic topical treatment with silver nitrate solution in some cases and disappeared spontaneously in 24-36 hours.
  • In the past, if maternal infection was suspected, a drop of silver nitrate solution 1% ;was instilled into each eye (Crede's method).
  • Now, this method is not used as silver nitrate itself causes chemical toxicity to the eyes.
  • It is rarely seen nowadays, as erythromycin and tetracycline eye ointment have replaced silver nitrate for prophylactic use.

Explanation of other options:

1% Sodium Fluorescein (Option A): Sodium fluorescein is a diagnostic dye used in ophthalmology. It is applied to the ocular surface to detect corneal epithelial defects or abrasions and is also used in angiography for retinal circulation studies. It does not cause chemical conjunctivitis in newborns.

3% Acyclovir (Option C): Acyclovir is an antiviral drug used for the treatment of herpes simplex keratitis and other viral infections. It does not have a role in neonatal prophylaxis, nor is it associated with causing chemical conjunctivitis.

1% Tetracycline (Option D): Tetracycline eye ointment was previously used as a prophylactic measure against ophthalmia neonatorum (especially chlamydial infections).
It does not cause chemical conjunctivitis. Nowadays, erythromycin has replaced tetracycline in many protocols, but neither is linked to chemical conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to OPD with complaints of itching, watering, redness and ropy discharge. Clinical imaging is as shown. Patient gives history of similar complaints every year in March/ April. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The above case is of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) :

  • Brief description, course and prognosis:
    • Recurrent, seasonal allergic conjunctivitis that affects both eyes
    • Most common in children and adolescents
    • Thought to be caused by an allergic reaction to pollen, dust mites, or other allergens
    • Chronic condition, but typically improves with age
    • Most children will outgrow VKC by their early teen years
  • Symptoms:
    • Itching
    • Burning
    • Redness
    • Tearing
    • Light sensitivity
  • Signs:
    • Palpebral VKC: Cobblestone-like papillae on the upper eyelids
    • Limbal VKC: ;White, gelatinous thickening of the limbus
    • Keratopathy is most common in limbal form and can take the form of punctate epitheliopathy, shield ulcer and secondary keratoconus
  • Treatment:
    • Topical therapy: Eyedrops containing antihistamines, mast cell stabilisers and/or steroids.
    • Triamcinolone injections sub-tarsally (under the tarsal conjunctiva) are not indicated in all cases of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). They are typically reserved for severe, refractory cases of VKC that do not respond to other treatment modalities.
    • Systemic therapy: Oral antihistamines
    • Supportive therapy: ;Cool compresses and tinted glasses
    • Surgery: In some cases, to remove giant papillae or to treat corneal ulcers

Explanation of other options:

Hay Fever Conjunctivitis(Option A): Also seasonal, but symptoms are milder, and redness and large papillae are absent.

Contact Keratoconjunctivitis(Option C): Related to allergens or irritants like contact lens use, not seasonal and less common in this age group.

Perennial Conjunctivitis(Option D): Symptoms persist throughout the year, usually due to allergens like dust mites or animal dander, not seasonal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not likely associated with Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis, the severe form of which is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC), is a specific type of allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • The underlying mechanism in GPC is a hypersensitivity reaction (types I and IV).
  • GPC is caused by long-term irritants to the conjunctival surface.
  • Cosmetic use is associated with contact dermato-conjunctivitis in acute settings, not in chronic settings. Hence, cosmetic use is not associated with GPC.
  • Giant papillae can be seen in other conditions, such as VKC and AKC(Option A).

Aetiology:

It usually occurs due to:

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lens use (Option B)
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prosthesis. (Option C)
  • After many years of rigid contact lens use.
